thread.title: Konekt has bought two Adelaide return-to-work firms to become the biggest SA rehab provider
thread.title_full: Konekt has bought two Adelaide return-to-work firms to become the biggest SA rehab provider | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The Advertiser

author: RICHARD EVANS
title: Konekt has bought two Adelaide return-to-work firms to become the biggest SA rehab provider
text:
AUSTRALIA’S largest private sector work rehabilitation provider is to expand its South Australian profile with the proposed acquisition of two state businesses.
Sydney headquartered Konekt Ltd yesterday agreed to buy the Enfield based Applied Innovative Services (AIS) and Innovative Training and Recruitment (ITR) along with the CBD located Insite Injury Management Group.
The purchases are intended to strengthen Konekt’s position in the state return to work market, while adding capability elsewhere in Australia said chief executive officer Damian Banks.
“We have been working on this for a while,” he said. “All of the providers of return to work services in SA have had to change their business models over the past two or three years. Konekt is doing very well nationally and we saw the opportunity to bring our business to SA.”
The consolidation will make Konekt the largest state rehabilitation provider he said with the match-up a perfect fit.
“The symbiosis of the three businesses allows for a complementary business that does not overlap.”
AIS and Insite have a strong standing with ReturnToWorkSA while Konekt has a reputation in the self-insured and government markets in SA Mr Banks said.
There will be no immediate change of name said Mr Banks.
“It’s business as usual for staff and customers. The businesses will operate in their own names initially so we will have four brands in SA.”
There may be a small number of administrative job losses he said but as a professional services firm that charges hourly, fee charging consultants roles will remain unchanged he said.
“We are not trying to shrink our way to glory.”
“This sale offers an opportunity for us to grow, yet recognises our strong history,” said Insite CEO Leah Brown.
The deals should be completed by next month and Mr Banks expects the acquisitions to contribute around $2.8 million in revenues this financial year.
Both sale prices are confidential.
